Home / Roth vs Traditional 401(k) when income varies year to year?
33

Roth vs Traditional 401(k) when income varies year to year?

Freelancer—some years high, some years lean. How do you decide between Roth vs pre‑tax contributions when MAGI and brackets swing? Any rules of thumb for 2025 tax year?

investing retirement taxes
Share Share on X Share on Facebook Share on LinkedIn Copied!
Xavier
August 9, 2025 at 09:10 AM

10 Answers

Top Answer
36

Framework: (1) Estimate this year’s marginal. (2) If ≥ 32% fed, go Traditional; if ≤ 22%, go Roth; 24% is a toss‑up—mix. (3) Re‑evaluate in Q4. (4) Use off‑years for Roth conversions up to the top of your chosen bracket.

Daria
August 9, 2025 at 02:47 PM
29

Tax arbitrage 101: contribute pre‑tax in high‑income years (marginal 32%+), switch to Roth in low years, and do Roth conversions in off years. Model with today’s brackets, not vibes.

CPA_Jules
August 9, 2025 at 12:13 PM
11

Spreadsheet sim: assume two scenarios with 6% real returns, different tax rates now vs later. Look at after‑tax balances, not pre‑tax totals (they lie).

Sven
August 9, 2025 at 11:52 PM
10

If you rely on ACA subsidies in lean years, be careful with Roth conversions—they can nuke your credit. Plan conversions outside subsidy windows.

Rajat
August 9, 2025 at 05:49 PM
7

Rule of thumb: if your present marginal > expected retirement marginal, go Traditional; otherwise Roth. Edge cases: ACA subsidies, QSBS, big one‑time deductions.

Aria
August 9, 2025 at 10:59 PM
6

Also watch state taxes. In a no‑tax state now but move later? Roth looks nicer. Opposite move? Pre‑tax wins.

Ken
2,100 reputation
August 9, 2025 at 05:08 PM
5

I split 70/30 Roth/Traditional most years as a hedge. Not optimal mathematically, but it keeps me saving. Behavior matters.

Tess
1,500 reputation
August 9, 2025 at 11:52 PM
4

Make a simple year‑by‑year table: income, deductions, marginal bracket, target contribution type. You’ll see the pattern fast. It’s… boring, which is good.

notlegaladvice
1,300 reputation
August 9, 2025 at 11:08 PM
3

If income whipsaws, consider defaulting to Traditional through the year and flip to Roth in Q4 once you can estimate bracket more precisely.

Mira
1,800 reputation
August 9, 2025 at 12:25 PM
2

Optionality > precision. The goal is saving enough; tax alpha is second order.

Mo
900 reputation
August 9, 2025 at 08:25 PM
